Award.AwardTitle: Innovative Model to Augment Technician Education for Manufacturing in the 21st Century

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
To be successful in the economy of today, industry requires multi-skilled technicians who possess both technical and non-technical skills. To address this need, this project at Thomas Nelson Community College (TNCC) in Virginia is designed to develop an innovative model to augment technician education with competencies that blend essential technical and non-technical skills and expand awareness of 21st century manufacturing. The model is in alignment with an advanced manufacturing competency model available through the U.S. Department of Labor that documents the skills and competencies required for workplace success in advanced manufacturing industries. The blended model for technician education will be utilized in the new Associate of Applied Science degree program in Advanced Integrated Manufacturing Technology (AIMT) at the college that was developed with industry partners to address an industry defined need for multi-skilled technicians in advanced manufacturing as well as in other technician education programs at the college and will result in students entering the workforce with 21st century skills. Expanding awareness of 21st century manufacturing will ensure that new talent is attracted to manufacturing to address the critical need for multi-skilled technicians.

Through collaboration with regional manufacturers and community partners, the goal of the project will be achieved through: 1) development of courses and modules that integrate non-technical competencies with technical content and 2) expansion of awareness of technical advancements and career opportunities in manufacturing through outreach activities to groups of potential students who may not have considered manufacturing as a career including high schools and veterans groups. With support of a planning grant provided in 2013 by the Virginia General Assembly, and several other regional studies conducted between 2011 and 2013, the college documented employer hiring needs for advanced manufacturing within the region. The AIMT program contains essential elements modeled after the ATE and NASA SpaceTEC program (DUE 1303935) that organizes students into cohorts that enter and progress through the program together and integrates academic instruction with rotating co-op/internship at multiple job sites under the supervision of subject matter experts (SMEs). An extensive evaluation is planned to determine the impact on worker performance of incorporating instruction on specific non-technical workplace competencies such as team building and diversity into the technician education program. The knowledge and application of non-technical competencies of students will be evaluated by comparing the non-technical competency and job performance of students in a cohort that did not receive the non-technical instruction with those of students in cohorts that receive that instruction. Activities can be replicated and integrated into advanced manufacturing degree programs and other science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) technician education programs offered at community colleges throughout the country. Materials highlighting the technical advancements of 21st century manufacturing and career opportunities will be developed and shared widely with secondary and post-secondary institutions and other stakeholders through the college website and social media outlets. The new model of technician education and promotional materials will be showcased through ATE Central, TeachingTechnicians.org, presentations at professional meetings, and web based communications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Innovative Model to Augment Technician Education for Manufacturing in the 21st Century (IMATEC) enhanced technical education in advanced manufacturing through two approaches:

  1. The incorporation and assessment of non-technical (soft) skills into advanced manufacturing and engineering technology courses at Thomas Nelson Community College.
  2. Professional development focused on non-technical skills for female STEM faculty from three southeastern Virginia Community Colleges. 

The project addressed the need for highly trained workers with both technical and non-technical skills that are most critical to employee success. The non-technical workplace skills on which this project focused were leveraged from a Virginia Community College System Soft Skills Task Force industry survey and direct recommendations from local industry leaders. The four major categories:

  • Communications - Listening, Speaking, Self-Management
  • Professionalism - Punctuality/Reliability, Attendance, Appearance, Work Ethic/Integrity, Organization, Time Management
  • Problem-Solving - Problem Identification, Adaptability, Solution Development, Critical Thinking
  • Teamwork - Interpersonal Skills, Enthusiasm/Attitude, Respect/Civility, Collaboration.

IMATEC successfully developed a model that blended technical and non-technical skills in nine advanced manufacturing and engineering technology courses, with multiple sections at three different enrollment levels (community college, dual enrollment, industry contracted). Additionally, the project gathered data on student demographics, and assessed student perceptions on the relative importance and preparedness of technical vs. non-technical skills. These results helped to determine teaching strategies.

The project not only integrated soft skills, but also assessed student learning of non-technical content. Overall, results indicate that growth was more significant in soft skill knowledge and application as a result of active learning, workplace scenarios vs. passive learning strategies. For example, assessment of rote or passive learning strategies resulted in the least improvement in teamwork-related knowledge, however, the teamwork category was most-improved in active learning scenarios. There was also a significant difference in growth per level of enrollment with community college students experiencing the most growth, followed by contract course students, then finally dual enrollment students. IMATEC results can help target strategies of teaching and learning of non-technical skills by population subtype.

The infusion of non-technical skills in to technical courses required a need for an increase in faculty knowledge. As a result, IMATEC offered a one-day professional development workshop for female community college STEM faculty. Faculty from Thomas Nelson Community College, Paul D. Camp Community College and Rappahannock Community College were in attendance.

Instructors were provided an opportunity to gain knowledge and enhance their own soft skills sets, and were introduced to non-technical teaching methods, and importance of assessment. This workshop also provided the framework for establishing a community of instructors, as well as future partnerships and collaborations.

The intellectual merit of the proposal is that it is informed by evaluation and examination, the outcome of which is a guide for practical and applied procedures in assessment and integration of soft skills into manufacturing and other engineering technology programs that prepare students with a greater holistic entry into STEM careers. The project advances knowledge on assessing the non-technical, job-related demands of technicians, provides knowledge on strategies for teaching and learning, and implements the inclusion of professional development for quality teaching of non-technical skills. 

The aim to broaden soft skill integration and student participation in the workforce is beneficial to society because it has the potential strengthen the workforce. Therefore, it is advantageous for ATE programs to address overall student knowledge both in technical and non-technical assessment of ALL skills required for careers in manufacturing. The assessment techniques provide quantitative data that can inform future research and implementation of non-technical skills into curriculum. The methods can also be adapted for job-performance applications. The findings of this project will be significant for educational programs and industries across the United States.
